My friend and I split that with the khinkali which was absolutely delicious, wish we had gotten more of that. However for the price I wouldn't say it was worth it, the sitting outside vibe was just okay and service wasn't very attentive. The interior of the place looked beautiful though but was empty.

Came here on a Saturday night and got reservations the day of. Not sure if you need them but better to be safe. It's a large restaurant so they have a lot of seating, would be a fun spot for a large group.
The waiter was really kind and helpful. We wanted to try a couple of the Kvevri wines and he brought over tastes to see what we wanted and helped us decide.
To eat we shared the beef & pork Khinkali which I liked and my friend loved. Also the Adjaruli which is always amazing, super rich and decadent but worth it. Also we got the chicken Mtsvadi which was pretty basic chicken kebabs but super flavorful and came with a great sauce. If you're with someone kind of a picky eater that would be a great option!
Fantastic experience we stayed and talked for a while and didn't feel rushed at all. Lovely spot!

Came here for lunch with a couple of friends and we all enjoyed the food a lot! I liked the interior decor a lot and thought our marble table was cute. We wanted to try a lot on their menu!

We settled on trying their lunch specials: 1. Chicken Liver Pie, 2. Chicken Wrap, 3. Mushrooms & Potatoes. My favorite of the three was the Chicken Liver Pie - I usually shy away from organs but it was super meaty and hearty! The chicken wrap was also good but the tarragon/herby flavor was very overwhelming. The mushrooms & potatoes were sooooo good. I think they put a stick of butter in the entire dish though because the bottom was just pooling with oil and wasn't very appetizing. I thought the salads could have used a wee bit more dressing.

They included 20% gratuity and a credit card charge, before we even gave them our card. If we had paid with cash, we would have gotten ripped off :/ and why include 20% tip if we're only 3 people? I thought restaurants usually only did that if you're a party of 6 or more.

Nevertheless it was great food and I want to go back one day to try their khinkali and adjaruli!

I genuinely love Georgian food! Despite this place is located just around the corner from my daughter's place, I hadn't tried it until this evening & I thoroughly enjoyed the experience.
It was a perfect spot for our family dinner on Sunday night before the Bway show . Authentic. Delicious . Intimate.

Don't recommend!

Food was so so, service is ok, but... Ordered drink, paid by card 12 bucks, then checked online and was astonished! Bartender took 15 dollars instead of 12!
Its very bad! I understand it's hard time for businesses, but steel money from customers? Never come again!

Had dinner at Oda House two nights ago, for the second time. Firstly, let me say that the restaurant is beautifully decorated and very charming. The menu is extensive and doesn't have a particular theme.  It varies from appetizers (hot and cold) to entrees.  There is such a wonderful variety to choose from!  I'm confident that you a person can fine on 10 separate occasions and not have tried everything on the menu. So here is what my brother and I feasted on:

Appetizer:  Khinkali (pork/beef dumplings). These are a must as they are incredibly flavored, and cooked with great attention/detail and love!

Entrees: Chakokhbili (chicken stew) & Chakapuli (lamb stew).  Please try them as they are slow cooked and prepared with the best combinations of savory herbs. The chef deserves a round of applause for their dedication and hard work!!  

Dessert: Shok--Manje (light chocolate mousse with cognac) Fantastic!

The staff are kind and welcoming.

I think as with most people, I have no frame of reference for Georgian food (other than a bottle of Georgian cherry sauce which I once brought in an Eastern European grocery store). That being said, the food we tried was largely unmemorable, which is a bit disappointing considering the prices.

For starters, we tried the chicken dumplings - which are very much like Nepali momos, though with less seasoning / taste. These were pretty good and a good sized portion for a $9 appetizer. Score: 3/5

For entrees:
One of us had a lamb entree - I wish I could remember the name - but it had a pretty distinct and interesting flavor that's hard to describe. Score: 4/5

Another had the Oda House Special - salmon covered with Georgian cheese and filled with some sort of mushroom-cheese sauce. I didn't try the salmon, but the cheese was delicious. Slightly less salty than feta, but with a firm/chewy texture like melted mozzarella. Score (for cheese only): 5/5

Another had the chicken cooked in the tomato sauce. It wasn't bad, but just completely unmemorable. Was hoping there would be some interesting spice or seasoning to make it different. It was 2/5.

The entrees came with pieces of homemade (?) bread that was delicious. Score: 5/5

For desert, we shared a piece of Maya tart. It was ok, but again, nothing about it really stood out. And for $14 (if memory serves me correct), one would expect a damn good piece of cake. Score: 2/5

Would definitely return for the cheese and bread, not so sure about anything else.
Wonderful restaurant. Food as wonderful. Their White wine was a great summer wine. Went Vegan this time, next time omnivore. Very good Vodka also

First time trying Georgian food-
The classics:
Khinkali w beef and pork - thick dough at the top, very juicy. Tastes exactly like Chinese dumplings minus garlic and ginger
Adrajuli - it was like a salty pizza boat minus the sauce, I loved it. The cheese wasn't pungent (which is good for me) and the yeasty dough was fluffy and springy.
Leek/spinach/eggplant trio - ordered this to get some veggies into our meal and it's honestly kind of bland.. the spinach and leek balls had walnuts in it I think? Eggplant had the most flavor

Would come back for the khachapuri, but will probably skip on the others.

We made a reservation for 4 on a Sunday for lunch and there was plenty of seating. So the winning dish had to be the Adjaruli (bread with rich cheese baked inside and a poached egg). The outer dough is buttery and soft to be used to dip into the cheese! We also ordered the Khinkali (beef and pork dumplings) which was just okay and personally felt the skin is too thick to enjoy. I suggest to skip the Phkhali Trio (3 dips of eggplant, spinach & leek with ground walnuts, fresh herbs & Georgian spices - it doesn't come with bread!). Their bread that came with the Oda House Eggs and their side order of bread was delicious. The house eggs had a smokey taste from the smoked pork belly and reminded me of a quiche. I would not recommend the Mushroom & potatoes, which was extremely oily. The wait staff was not very helpful or friendly; in fact he told us that next time we should not order the Mushroom & potatoes since it is not considered traditional Georgian food, we asked to remove it but he said he already put in the order...
I would come back to try the other dishes but was a little underwhelmed since I heard good things about this place.

Came here dinner with friends and it was an amazing experience. The food was different. It was fresh and different. It was my first time eating Georgian food. We had the sampler, borscht soup, kharcho soup, adjaruli (cheese bread), kebab, lobio rachuli, imeruli, chakapuli, and other dishes. The server was helpful and on top of us. The lighting was a bit dim at the beginning until we told the waitress it was too dark, then they lit up the room. We were seated in their outdoor patio at their back. I would say this place is pretty nice and great for hangout. They had plenty of space to seat a party of 10 ppl. I will definitely come back again for more Georgian food. This place really hit the spot
Party of 10 - tried a lot of things (close to 15 different dishes), everything was really good! definitely recommend this place if you are looking for good Georgian food. Try it, you won't regret it

Absolutely love this restaurant. We went twice in one month because the Lula Kabab was just sooo good. The cheese bread was also a new experience and absolutely delicious. Highly recommend this restaurant!

Nice interior.  Good service.  First time trying Georgian ( the country) food.
We had small Megruli for starters.  Good size for 2 people for appetizer.  Was hot and melty with very nice flavor.
I had the Lula kabob with beef/pork.  Came rolled in very thin bread with red sauce on the side.  I thought it was delicious and I did not think it was too salty.  My husband had Mtsvadi with lamb.  Kabob came on top of a thin bread that he wasn't sure what to do with.  Roll it?  Didn't feel like all the meat/veg would fit so he just took bites with the kabob as he went along.
He did like the kabob very much.
Had Maya cake for dessert.  It was served cold which is not our preference for cake like this.
Overall, a very nice meal.  I would definitely come back and try other items on the menu.  I really felt like I was getting to try a different cuisine that has not been "adapted" to US tastes but maybe it was - just a more subtle approach. :)

I've dined in this restaurant several times, but tonight is my first night ordering delivery! Fingers crossed! I'm excited!

The restaurant has a really cute interior, and the vibe is nice. It's a bit dim, but that's part of the mood. :)

I appreciate that this restaurant is at a volume where you can have a conversation with the people you're dining with. What can I say? I'm becoming a bit of a biddy! I wouldn't bring kids here for that reason though. But who knows. Maybe no one cares!

I have some favorites to order from this restaurant, which I'll save for another day. Even if not every dish has been a home run-- I have wholeheartedly enjoyed every meal here! This has become my go to restaurant on the UES.

This is my favorite Georgian restaurant in Manhattan. I would have to travel into Brooklyn to get something on par-- so glad that Oda is in the neighborhood.

Second visit wasn't as good.

The wine was to die for as always. Get the Kindzmarauli, it's a sweet red wine and a Georgian delicacy. I had two glasses and still couldn't get enough. The food was very delicious. Their cheeseboats and dumplings literally never miss.

However, I think management could be a bit more professional. Our server was sweet - but maybe relax on the staring and conversations in Georgian? Seems like you're talking shit about customers and no one wants to assume anything. Also, the bartender/dude who couldn't greet us properly when we walked in, maybe you should NOT do your restaurant's finances (or whatever homework you were doing) in the same room as your customers. It's weird.

Delicious Georgian food!
Homemade specialties and bread.
The meat dumplings are addictive.
Cheese heavy menu that's delicious!

I went here on my usual Sunday friend lunch. I have always loved Georgian cuisine especially the cheesy bread but I have become vegan and so I was anxious about the menu.  They have good vegan options. I had the lobio which was a hearty meal compliant to my dietary requirements. I enjoyed it very much. My friend got the salmon and loved it too. We also enjoyed the Georgian dry sparkling wine. It is well decorated and the setrvice was very friendly and pleasant. I don't know what folks were complaining about. They did not add 20% gratuity to our bill. Thanks to everyone who pointed out. I wonder if they changed that seeing all the complaints. We happily gave the 20% but I would have missed it if the yelpers did not warn me. We are definitely adding Oda house in our Sunday rotating list.

I sat and thought reasonably about this for quite a while:

-made a specific reservation for inside the outside hut. I'd actually called TWICE about this AND indicated it on the online res, and they verbally confirmed twice. Upon arrival, they said we couldn't sit there and only had space outside on the sidewalk.

-it smelled like stale mop water the entire evening. It wafted everywhere.

-tables uneven, so the entire evening liquids were spilling everywhere.

-the staff is INCREDIBLY rude. Not brusque, culturally, but outright rude and mean. I've been in NYC 20 years and have a thick skin. There is no reason for this rudeness. Main host came out to actually YELL at us. I don't know how these people are in the hospitality business.

-the service is incredibly slow. Even slower than you'd think, with all these warnings.

-the food is good/ok. Totally bland, and very cheesy/heavy. Interesting spices, but bland in any case. With all the above, totally not worth it. I actually had to ask for salt. I've done this maybe 3x in my entire life.

-they completely forgot one of our dishes and it came out after 95% of our dinner was up

-they charged a TWENTY PERCENT AUTO GRATUITY WITHOUT MENTION ANYWHERE, for a TABLE OF THREE.

-HUGE headache from the unfiltered wine. I rarely get headaches from wine, but this one lasted an entire day.

Honestly I would never come back here, and never suggest it to anyone. Terrible experience, dining-wise, so much that I feel I have to warn others. There are about a million more options in the few -block vicinity. Why bother. This is insanity. So happy my dining companions made it all worthwhile.

What a great experience walking into such a warm and welcoming community-- I could immediately sense the staff's pride and passion for their food and their heritage. On the two occasions I went, I met Nico, Sandra and Marishka. Their genuine kindness and attentiveness to me made me feel happy just to arrive! My server helped explain the dishes I was unfamiliar with and made great suggestions.  I tried a variety of plates, and was shocked by how good the Borscht soup was. I have never tried borscht that was so flavorful and rich! I can't wait to have it again! But everything was delicious! I immediately appreciated the freshness of each ingredient. The space is elevated, but homey. It felt intimate and relaxing in a way that made it really wonderful to savor the food and the experience. A great place to go for a date and a fun adventure for someone who is unfamiliar with Georgian food. I am a vegan and was pleasantly surprised to find non-dairy and meat free items on the menu. Im really excited to return soon and try more items.

Ordered 2 vegetarian items, borscht the soup and lobio.. interesting seasoning... in my opinion it lacked salt, maybe that's how my palate is set.. definitely worth checking out.
Food served in hot pot was nice, it stayed hot longer

First time trying Georgian food and Oda House delivered! The adjaruli was phenomenal (it's bread eggs and cheese so how could it not be?) and was my favorite dish. Will be back to try the Georgian wine next time!
Came here mostly for the adjaruli and it did not disappoint. Creamy, gooey cheesy goodness that hit all the spots.

My boyfriend and I went here on a date. This place is amazing. The staff were very helpful in giving recommendations. All the food was extremely delicious. Posted photos of all the food we ate. If you are in the area you should check it out 100%.

Every time I travleed to NYC, I visited Oda House in their East Village location many times before the pandemic.  I was delighted to find they were still around in Manhattan (new location on the upper East Side) and with another location in Brooklyn when I came back to NYC this year.  

Their food is amazing!!! I wish I could ship it home to me. If you haven't had Georgian food, you need to try it!

They also have excellent, hospitable service.  

On my most recent visit, I had the imerli khatchipourri, the eggplant quartet appetizer (the ones with pkhali are my favorite), the ideali honey walnut cake for desert, and the danieli red wine.  

I will definitely be returning to Oda House on all my future visits to NYC.

The appetizers here are amazing every time I go. I recommend their version of Georgian style soup dumplings. I believe these were the mixed meat beef and pork ones. This cheesy bread was good but the one with the egg yolk mixed on top is even better as i've had that in the past. The entrees are ok but for me this is really a place to go and share a bunch of apps if looking to try a unique cuisine fl style. Last time I ordered a minced lamb entree dish which they usually cook one temperature according to the waitress. I made the mistake of asking for it more on the medium rare aids and it came out and was actually raw inside. Not just rare but raw. Stick to the apps and you won't be disappointed.

Was so sad to hear the other oda house closed! We still wanted our Georgian food fix so we headed to this location and it has a bit of a different vibe to it. Much more romantic setting with dimmer lighting and classy music.

Always order the adjaruli, after you scramble it its like a really rich tasting egg and cheese mixture with some  tasty bread to boot. We also ordered the Tulsa and lamb khinkalis which are also worthy of mention.

Mains were the lamb mtsvadi and the apkhazura. We really enjoyed both but the apkhazura was pretty interesting as its a classic meatball with pomegranate seeds inside.

The desserts here are fantastic, the shok was amazingly decadent and despite being completely full we were still able to make room for it.

These restaraunts have been my first expirienec with Georgian food and I'm happy to say that it is now in my top cuisines after dining here

This is my second time eating at Oda House. My first time was probably 10 years ago in the Brooklyn location and I remember it being delicious. I am happy the opened a location near my work in UES! The restaurant is charming, spacious and clean. The staff is very friendly and make great recommendations. I went with 4 of my friends and we were comfortable at the table. The food: as delicious as I had remembered! I will be dreaming of khachapuri . The dishes are shareable (if you want to share) . The cocktails were also tasty. I did not try the wines, but I might next time. highly recommend this place especially for the winter/fall because the food is cozy and rich . But cheesy bread is good in the summer too haha

Adjaruli 10/10 you will want the regular size haha
Imeruli 9/10 not as wow factor as adjaruli but delicious like a white pie pizza
Oda special zhulien khinkali 9/10 love earthiness of mushrooms
Chvishtari 7/10 like an pan fried arepa with a mild satay sauce
Elarji 7/10 was like cheese grits with beef stew
Lula kebab 7/10 beef/pork was ok and buttery mash was good
Ideali 10/10 walnut cake was nutty and just sweet enough
Napoleoni 8/10 it was good but would've been better with fresh fruit to cut the creaminess, which I've had in other restaurants

So I have never had Georgian food before, so this was quite the experience. The place itself is super cute, and food was good!

We also had some Georgian wine that was quite delicious and went with the food well. We ordered the appetizer platter, which was definitely the move. All the different types of salads, and the eggplant was great to be able to have a sample.
We also ordered the mushroom dumplings and then one of the cheese breads. To be honest I wasn't blown away by the cheese bread that we ordered, like it was good, but it wasn't as good as the other stuff. The flavors just didn't taste as explosive as they could have, which is strange because I think that is what they are most known for. However, there were several different types of cheese bread and we may have not ordered the best one.

Great food, excellent service , Friendly Ambiance
I will definitely go back again soon.

Was so happy to try this neighborhood joint on a quiet street with a really charming outdoor patio. A friend and I split the two dishes and were really satisfied with the portions, leaving not too full but very content.

The cheese bread was not overwhelmingly rich as you would expect other cheese breads to be. It was crispy, warm and balanced really well with the egg.

The dumplings were quite similar to Chinese Soup Dumplings but with a more Mediterranean spice palette.

Will definitely be coming back!

Awesome new spot for the neighborhood, worth traveling for. Great ambiance for a date or post work drinks, and excellent cocktails (especially for the price).

Highly recommend checking out this new spot before it blows up. Service is neighborhood friendly and makes you feel like home!

This is a new, vibe-y spot in SoHo with romantic lighting, a variety of seating situations, and really good service. My date and I found it on a whim while walking around SoHo on a Saturday evening around 5:30 pm-ish, and we were able to walk in with no wait.

We originally planned only for drinks but ended up staying for food, and the price was reasonable ($100ish for 2 people) given the location, intended vibes (classy date night or bougie group hang), and quality + portion size of food.

The cocktails are super solid - I got an espresso martini that was right on up there with any other nice restaurant I've been to in the city. In terms of food, my date has gluten and nut allergies, and we were happy to see that the kitchen was willing and able to make modifications (e.g. they can serve the odd sister burger without the bun - note that it comes with french fries that have been probably been fried with other gluten products though; kale salad without nuts; duck skewers were recommended as another option). I got the popcorn chicken appetizer for myself and thought it was not particularly memorable, but tasty. I would come back!

Stopped by for some quick bites before dinner based on their menu but arrived to a different menu. The for the table plates were pretty expensive for the portion.

Miso Hummus - the pita bread was very fluffy and flavorful. There were only four long slices of pita bread  and not enough to get through half of the hummus. We asked if we could get a little more and to our surprise, they charged us for it.

Beet salad - the beet salad flavors were not balanced well. It felt very bland. I've definitely had better beet salads.
The appetizers were excellent. So flavorful and really interesting flavors. Will definitely return for the tuna tartare alone. The kale salad was also amazing

Found this place as it was one of the few restaurants around the area that had a reservation. Came in for drinks, which were great and less expensive than I expected, and ended up sharing a pizza. Also great. The hostess/waitress was fantastic, very attentive, engaging. The place is beautiful. Would definitely be back, and this time for a more complete meal!

Great ambience and relaxing vibe, a great experience from start to finish. The hostesses were warm and welcoming and the bartender and all staff were terrific. I loved loved loved the Maude cocktail and the miso hummus was delicious and beautiful. I look forward to getting back in to sit down for dinner and try more from the interesting menu.
Walked by and stopped in for a drink. And what a drink it was - expertly crafted. Beautiful little romantic spot that I look forward to having dinner at.

Randomly walked in tonight and sat at the bar. Those steak bites  I will travel all the way from BK for that dish again! The bartender was very friendly and knowledgeable of drinks! Can't wait to go back!

Wow!!! The newest SoHo gem.  We love this place.  The food is great (super chef), the cocktail concoction's are amazing (the bartenders are professional mixologists)....and the entire staff is great.  The ambiance has a vibe that makes you want to come back before you ever leave.

Definitely a cool place to rent out for a party

I avoided Odea for months because the weekend crowd seemed a little too 'long island bar' (I don't know how else to describe it) and the music was fairly awful and overly loud in that obnoxious way only bad music can be. I gave in and went with friends tonight, and well, it was everything I feared. The saving grace of this place, however, are the 3-4 large U-shaped couches in the back, complete with curtains to close them off. If you go with a small group of friends and order a few bottles of wine (priced at about $35) you can have a great time despite it all. Or better yet rent it out for a party and switch up the DJ's playlist.

Cool space with nicely cordoned off areas for you and your group of friends.

Sorry, but you can't call yourself a bar if you only have 15 people inside on a Saturday night at 12 am. Sheesh!
Great place to throw a party.  Cool space with good munchies.

TLDR: go.

Came here for lunch and had zero expectations. There was no menu, and from what I gathered online, the menu was constantly changing and evolving anyway.

From the first bite of my asparagus starter, I knew that I was in for something special. Everything was equally delicious, but if I had to choose one item to highlight, it would be the charcoal grilled duck with sansho pepper and soy reduction, black truffle, and lotus root stir fry. I didn't want the dish to end. I'm going to be bold and say it was the best duck I've ever had. Lunch was easily one of the best meals I've experienced and I eat out quite a lot!

The restaurant is speakeasy style, located behind a bar. Once you open the door, you'll find a small bar seating area around a kitchen. Pretty cool. Service was kind and friendly and I loved that the server was eager to answer my many questions. They only serve tasting: lunch is 145 and dinner is 245, so go for special occasion or treat yourself!

Overall: Not sure why this place only has a 4.3 on Yelp. One of the best meals I've had and I hope to return for dinner soon.

Highlights:
- great value lunch menu
- very attentive and caring service
- nice counter seating with very few people on weekday lunch time
- impressive first course

Cons:
- other courses were not impressive, especially the dessert

We were able to snag a lunch reservation thankfully to this Michelin star establishment on very short notice. Odo immediately transported me back to Tokyo with its decor and ambiance, which made me reminisce about the wonderful fine dining experiences from a recent trip. The atmosphere is very zen-like with the kitchen working harmoniously in virtual silence.

Our menu included the following:

Asparagus (asparagus foam, golden caviar, vinegar jelly), soup (shima aji, lotus root tofu, baby lotus root, scallion, yuzu, junsai), Long Island duck (Australian black truffle, sansho pepper, lotus root), mini chirashi (chutoro, tai, ikura, kinmedai), house-made soba (Kumamoto wagyu, kaireki, micro shiso), and a dessert of milk flavored soft serve with amaou strawberry.

Unfortunately, there was no written menu so I'm recollecting the menu items from the best of my abilities from the descriptions of the wait staff. I would rate the food as near immaculate with both the aesthetic presentation and the taste.

The lunch service started off strong with a wonderful asparagus dish with accompanying asparagus foam, golden caviar (I'm assuming kaluga given the price point of the meal), vinegar jelly, and shiso flower blossom. This dish was a perfect representation of the transition from spring to summer with the cool foam and acidic vinegar jelly providing both a refreshing and bright bite when shuffled with the luxurious pearls of golden caviar. I would definitely say that this dish and the soba noodles were the highlights of my meal here.

The soup course prominently featured lotus root both in tofu form and sliced form. The shima aji was tender and succulent as it was immersed in the base of the soup. The soup itself was subtly flavored and allowed the lotus root tofu to be the focus of the dish. The yakimono course featured Long Island duck with the optional supplement of Australian black truffle. The duck itself was succulent and simply prepared while having a slight heat from the sansho peppercorn while being paired beautifully with the shaved black truffle which gave off its typical earthy aroma. The mini chirashi course was cute, with three pieces of sashimi from 3 types of fish (bluefin tuna, tai, kinmedai) with ikura on top. All of the proteins were expertly prepared and sliced, providing a small taste of each while not imposing a large volume of food as a standalone course.

The star of the show was the house-made soba noodles. This soba had the perfect bite; it was not gummy and had the proper density, bounciness, and thickness. The rare slices of Kumamoto wagyu served as a wonderful accoutrement to the noodles as the textures of both melded very well together due to their relative thinness. The herbal notes from the micro shiso and other vibrant green herbs added a refreshing vegetal component to the shoyu based broth and buckwheat from the soba.

The dessert was definitely not an afterthought, albeit it was a bit melted by the time it got presented to us. The texture of the soft serve was velvety smooth with a pronounced milk flavor. The amaou strawberry was treated with just enough sugar to serve as a perfect pairing to this soft serve ice cream.  

This was a wonderful meal that I'll soon not forget. I would love to come to this establishment again for dinner service.

Odo was overall a fun experience. All the courses were yummy. 9 courses was too much food for me but it was worth the experience. Wish they had a smaller course option. The sake flight was also fun and definitely recommend!

We stopped by for lunch without a reservation.
Thy have a serene ambiance with friendly service.
We had the tasting menu that started with a toro tartare with caviar and ikura, followed by 6 panko breaded skewers and 8 nigiris.
Presentation is beautiful and everything was delicious.

This is 4.5 stars rounded up to 5. Enjoyed the food and ambiance and left feeling pretty full, which is rare for me - even had some rice with roe to bring home for my husband! I didn't walk away thinking it blew my mind (which is what I usually reserve for 5 stars) but everything was still really great in terms of both food and service.

There's also a really cool bar in front that looks to have good burgers and other food options.

I came here for lunch in Oct. The place was really quiet and had a calm vibe. The food was really good. The appetizer looked like a masterpiece on a seashell. The fish soup and other courses were also super delicious. I wish the softserve was less sweet, or had more strawberry compose which balanced out the sweetness. The waitress explained every course and was really attentive.
Overall, it was a nice experience and totally worth it.

Food is good. I will give 4/5.
Service is quite horrible given the price and gratuity.
I will not be back again. Very rude and not attentive.

Secretly located on one of business blocks in the city, Odo offers its exquisite omakase courses with their limited seatings. Artistically built the gallery next to dining area was where we had private tasting course lunch.  Their raw fishes, tempura, sushi and meat course was somewhat experimental but all were delicious. Coming for dinner at main dining area soon!

Overall delicious. But for $125 tasting menu, you can get much more courses at like Kochi, Jua, 63 Clinton and more that's around the similar level.
So there's that in between lines.

2022 April :

First course - Chawamusbi Uni Caviar ::: basic starter which is safe. Good quality but no surprise.

Second course - Fish & Veggie Soup ::: light, fresh, clean, homey, very good but for some reason not satisfying, maybe because the proportion is small for a soup

Third course - A5 Wagyu Cube ::: pretty good, sauce was good too. Few little bits as well lol

Forth course - Mini Chirashi ::: very mini yet very good. 2 pieces of Chutoro and 1 white tuna something. The quality of the fish was beyond. Rice was cooked to perfection. Very balanced and enjoyable.

Fifth course - Duck with Homemade soba ::: the duck pieces were my favorite of the night. Very tender and tasty, juicy but not overpowering. I'm not a soba person so ~

Sixth course - Strawberry something ::: it was kinda nothing special.

Overall, since the dessert wasn't memorable and not much effort, it really is a 5 course menu, with the price, I'd say overall portion is small (even for me I'm a girl).

I asked for the menu at the end of the meal wanting to remember what I had. The captain said we change menu often so we don't print it anymore. Not really something I would expect from a Michelin 1 star restaurant. She said she would email me the menu but she never did.

Let's start by making one thing clear: Kaiseki is not the same as omakase. You can always tell the true foodies from the posers (there are so many in NYC) by whether they: 1) Know what kaiseki is; 2) Have had true kaiseki; and 3) Don't use kaiseki and omakase interchangeably.

Odo is a true kaiseki restaurant that--thankfully--refuses to dumb itself down for the omakase sheep. Sadly reduced to serving just lunch due to pandemic-era issues, it is nevertheless one of the few kaiseki restaurants on this coast that actually understands what kaiseki is and does it well.

Every one of our courses was designed to showcase the breadth of Japanese culinary mastery and the diversity of seasonal Japanese produce. I'm annoyed that the manager never emailed me a copy of the menu he promised me (he said they didn't have printed copies), so I'll do my best to detail what we got from memory:

#1: Chawanmushi with caviar - Deliciously comforting and served at the perfect temperature.

#2: Kinmetai Soup - Slightly oily but in all the right ways due to the seared fish, and chock full of seasonal vegetables.

#3: A4 Seared Wagyu beef with white asparagus - Can't remember the two sauces that were served with it, but they were a bit too salty. The beef was good enough on its own.

#4: Chirashi - Served with bluefin tuna and another cut of fish that I forget. Light, easy, simple, and fresh.

#5: Housemade buckwheat soba with seared duck breast and eggplant - I normally don't like shoyu broth, but this had a particular dimension that was compelling. The duck was perfectly cooked, and the soba were incredibly chewy (and I'm not the biggest soba fan either).

#6: Dessert - Hokkaido milk soft-serve ice-cream with fresh strawberry sauce.  A bit disappointingly simple, but well made--especially that sweet, sweet Hokkaido milk flavor

Odo isn't the best kaiseki I've ever had, but it does a good job in a city that--for all its world-class dining--is woefully bereft of this highest level of Japanese cuisine (seriously, why do omakases dominate when kaiseki is literally haute cuisine?).

THIS WAS AN AMAZING MEAL!!! I always want to try a few Michelin restaurants when I am visiting New York and this trip I ate at 3 Michelin star places. Odo was by far the best of the three, and also the most affordable!!!

I came here for lunch and the restaurant is fairly small/intimate. I was lucky to get reservations a few days before. The service was great and every seat allows of a great view into the kitchen. There would two chefs and they were working like crazy to provide the costumers with a flawless experience.

When I sat down, I was presented with a drink menu. I was pleasantly surprised to see that there were nonalcoholic cocktail options since I don't drink alcohol. I ordered that and also added the truffle supplement to the pre fixi menu because the supplement was actually pretty reasonably priced (I think like $30 for a very generous heap of fresh truffles - the last of the season!)

Every dish that came out was AMAZING. All the broths were so flavorful and rich. The waygu was some of the BEST I ever had, despite being A4. It was way better than all the other wagyu I have had at Michelin star places (except maybe it's on par with per se's). The eggplant was DIVINE which is funny since it is literally just eggplant. The noodle was perfectly chewy and Al Dante. All the sashimi was melt in your mouth, even the lean tuna. The strawberry dessert was SO fresh and sweet, and they didn't add any sugar to it!! Literally everything was so different and fulfilling. My heart was so happy at the end of the meal. This was literally one of the best meals I have had and it was very reasonable priced (for a Michelin star restaurant) at $125. I would highly HIGHLY recommend this place if you are in New York!

It was a high quality of food and delicious like a home town in Japan. The customer service was really as a professional and taking care of people frequently. If you know what is "dashi" this place that you can tasty well.
This is 100% you must resavation. They do have a special seat for each person in counter.

Odo is an excellent kaiseki restaurant that showcases a number of Japanese foods and preparations. The restaurant is intimate, the staff are friendly and knowledgeable, and the chefs brilliantly execute the menu.

I typically visit omakase sushi restaurants and had never visited a kaiseki restaurant before. While I had seen pictures on Instagram of the changing menu over the past few months, I was not sure what to expect. Odo is a kappo restaurant. Kappo is a multi-course meal that can feature a number of foods including sashimi, sushi, tempura, and meat. It is also characterized by the casual setup of the restaurant and emphasizes the proximity between the diner and the chef who cuts and cooks the food before the diner's eyes.

I visited Odo this afternoon for lunch and was treated to a delicious 6-course menu featuring hairy crab+scallop, madai miso soup, A5 Kagoshima Wagyu roast beef, chirashi, cold soba with grilled duck breast, and soft serve ice cream with strawberries. Each dish featured a variety of ingredients and showcased a variety of skills.

While I enjoyed each and every course, the chirashi that I was served was one of the most magnificent dishes I have ever eaten. It featured sushi rice topped with chutoro, akami, kakimi (scraped tuna mixed with Japanese mustard), shime saba (pickled mackerel), and suzuki (black bass). Additionally, I'd like to give an honorable mention to the grilled duck breast that topped the house-made cold soba noodles. The char was delicious and the skin had a nice layer of fat underneath.

I cannot adequately describe how incredible of a time I had this afternoon. Odo is one of the most spectacular restaurants I have eaten at in New York (and Japan). I was sad when the meal came to a close and look forward to returning for lunch (and hopefully dinner) in the near future. Thank you Brian for your hospitality. 5/5.

Odo was a gem during our trip to NYC. We had been exploring the city and walked on over to Odo. The spot is very unassuming with a lot of little storefront but once you are inside you feel like you've been transported into a small Japanese restaurant. Almost like a speakeasy! We were one of the 10ish guests at the chefs table. The lunch menu is an abbreviated kaiseki but they all tasted great! The best, of course, was the wagyu beef course that was just so flavorful, fatty, and tender. The other courses were all cooked immaculately. The only semi-disappointment was the dessert which felt like soft serve so kind of a sad way to end the meal. Nonetheless a great meal, with great service and worth the price.

The food was ok and the server was nice. However, they should be a lot better for the price they charge.  
The service:  We were the last seating for lunch and there were only 2 other customers besides us so not busy at all.  These 2 other customers were Japanese so it was understandable that the main chef was chatting up a storm with them.  However, we felt snubbed as the chef didn't even acknowledge us with a smile or even look our direction at all the entire meal.  Those two customers left a bit earlier than us so the chef basically just cleaned up and left after them without even looking our way.  
The food:  They were ok but comparing to other Japanese restaurants in that price range in NYC, they should be a lot better.

Wonderful omakase at Odo (visited in Oct 2022). Simple ingredient but with their magic the food had the most beautiful flavor. We felt our minds were calmed and touched after the meal. Will definitely come back!

We came to try the restaurant week menu, and it was definitely a unique experience. It was a hand roll set that came in a bento box, where each compartment slides out like a drawer. We also had cauliflower soups to start, and cheesecake and chocolate cake for dessert. The food was good but my only complaint was that everything came out a little cold/room temperature. It might have been prepared a while ago, and there didn't seem to be enough servers as service was a little slow.

A perfectly homely meal that will leave you full. We enjoyed dinner at Odo. Service was attentive without being overbearing. It was nice seeing the chef at work, and the smoke and fire in the kitchen. Everything was nicely cooked, showcasing the ingredients in a minimalist way. I appreciated that nothing was too flashy.

One star off for the experience at the door. The male bartender at the outer bar was rude and condescending. Upon entering, we asked if this was Odo, and he yells at us. What a turn off.

My friend booked here for dinner for her birthday. Pretty intimate ambiance for dinner. Service was really good. Good is pretty good. But there's nothing special or amazing here. I would come back and recommend. But this is my friends top restaurant that she likes. She's likes eating these type of food. But when she says this is one of her favorite place. I was expecting something amazing. But it's pretty good. Can't complain. Unique flavors!

Seriously good Kaiseki. It felt like I was at a Japanese restaurant in Japan, not New York. Everything was delicious and presentation was beautiful. We loved the Chawamushi, Toro tartare with caviar, fish soup, house made soba noodles, and the wagyu! Wonderful and thoughtfully nuanced flavors. Expensive but worth it.

This lovely little Japanese spot sits a bit hidden in flatiron. You may miss it on the street and when you walk in the speakeasy vibe might make you wonder. Rest assured, behind the back door sits a beautiful omakase room. It is quiet, it is clean, it is beautiful. I think this atmosphere is a big part of why they have earned one Michelin star. The service is stellar and the pace of the meal is perfect. The food is very good. Each dish is solid. I could pick apart little things but I won't. Both soup dishes were the highlight. I will do wish there was more sushi. And I feel the lunch course load for the price is maybe one or two courses lacking. Not my favorite Japanese tasting menu in town, but still solid and worth a try. Ps I think they are now open for dinner too.

Whenever I visit New York, I always like to check out at least one Michelin star restaurant. Odo has been on my list for a bit and I'm so glad we finally got to try it.

Just based on the food Odo deserves 5 stars! The food was that good. From the first dish to the sashimi to the soup to the A3 & A4 wagyu to the Donabe rice, every dish was outstanding. The toro literally melted in your mouth. We added truffles to the A3 wagyu and they did not hold back. It was like eating truffles with a side of meat. It was our first time having raw egg yolk & soy sauce with meat and we loved the combination. The quality of the A4 wagyu was amazing and it melted in your mouth. The dessert of ice cream with a watermelon sauce was fantastic and nothing like we had eaten before. We were thinking about this meal days after.

I do wish the ambiance was a little better. It was so quiet that we sometimes felt uncomfortable speaking above hushed voices, maybe some background music could help. Also would have loved a copy of a written menu since the explanation of the food was sometimes quick & confusing.

But we're going for the food and I would highly recommend Odo for a fantastic Kaiseki dinner experience!
Beautiful, interesting, tasty food with so many flavors and textures. And service is fantastic too.
Owner chef Odo-san and his partner Chef Ishizaki-san presents ultimate Omakase dining experience w authentic Kaiseki meets French and wagyu flare and outstanding service

Michelin Star food during quarantine is always a win and this was beyond affordable! Let's dive in...

French Fries (4/5): These could have used a little more garlic flavor but the roasted brussel sprouts were delectable. Fries tasted/looked like they might have been frozen but I can't verify that. The ketchup was good and the mustard with soy sauce was a bit odd.

Chef Special - Tuna Tartar Sandwich (5/5): Wow this was incredible! The tuna melts in your mouth while the salmon roe bursts in little pockets. The brioche bun was toasted and very fresh. The little diced red onion further enhanced this.

Hall Salad (4/5): The gem lettuce was very fresh and had a nice spice on it. The soft boiled egg was a perfectly firm egg white with creamy dark yellow middle. We were confused by the egg salad and potato salad which felt random and were somewhat plain.

Wagyu Burger (5/5) (Girlfriend's review): Full flavored burger, good cheese, onion, and sweet but not overwhelming sauce.

Price (5/5): Amazingly priced for Michelin Star grub.

TL;DR: Would order again here in a heartbeat. Such a treat with all the world's stressors!

Feels like eating at a high end Tokyo place.  Great food, great service and very good price especially for lunch.  I have eaten there for now about 10 times and always consistently good.  I recommend eating at the counter that sits around 13 people.  At the counters you can see the two chefs preparing and cooking.  Very good wine and sake list as well.

After one and half year close due to pandemic, I am glad they survived and returned.  We went there for the newly offered lunch Omakase.

The dark room entrance highlights a mysterious impressions of the scene offered behind the wooden sliding door. Right after that, it is a 14 seats bar / kitchen setting in a minimalist setting of the wooden bar.

The service was superb, the food was great. However,  it did feel like the place suddenly paused right before the pandemic and has not been refreshed.  I will give them time since they had just reopened for a month. The chef did his best with fresh local ingredients and flavorful tastes.  LOVE the opening cold corn soup with botan ebi (shrimp) and uni (sea urchin).  The two fishes in grilled and soupy offering are flavorful.  The final main dishes of the mini chirashi and wagyu home made noodle completed the appetize.  

We go to omakase chef table for the ambiance,  quality of the food, the amazing preparation right in front of your eyes and super service.  They did receive the 1 Micheline star. I hope they continue to reinvigorate and I will return.

Everything you'd expect from a Michelin-starred restaurant. I sat at the chef's counter, which was astonishingly quiet and orderly. I was able to whisper to the other people in my party.

Each dish was as delicious as the last, with the real highlights being truly special. Our first course was an out-of-this-world miso steam egg with uni and caviar. It achieved a level of balance that is incredibly hard to find. Hands-down everybody's favorite was the cubes of A5 Wagyu steak cooked to absolute perfection. It was my first experience with Wagyu and it exceeded all expectations. Absurdly delicious.

Service was as good as service could possibly be. The only area I found lacking was the drink selection. Two of us got the sake flight and I was a bit let down by the presentation. All three sakes were served at once, rather than paired with the correct dishes, which meant that all made it to room temp by the time any were finished; and we had no idea if we were meant to drink them each to completion or all together or what. They also didn't do the best job at explaining each one. They told us the idea of each (this is a clean sake with some fruity notes) but nothing of their origin, how they were made, and only surface level tasting notes.

Still the food was masterful and service impeccable. The place is pretty hard to find, which honestly inhibited the experience for us. Well worth the price.

Chef Odo is one of the most brilliant chefs in New York City. His amazing work at Kaijitsu and now at his namesake ODO is unsurpassed. A true culinary experience each and every time with new seasonal dishes. I honestly cannot say enough good about this restaurant. I have been many times and it is never disappointing. Hits all the senses with the aromas, visually beautiful presentation, acoustics of the crackling hot dishes and crunchy bits, textures, and the out of this world flavors. I implore everyone to go but not too often as I want to still be able to get a seat.

One of my favorite Japanese restaurants to return to!

Their dishes are always perfectly made and super fresh! Loved the sea urchin appetizer as it was unique and super refreshing. The flavors blended very well together. Also, can't go wrong with salmon sashimi, which was tasty too. The wagyu beef was tender and was cooked to perfection!

Overall, highly recommended!

Had a great meal here. Loved all the local foods incorporated into the meal. Made it different and special compared to other Izakaya menus.
I really loved the sushi course as I had fish I wouldn't normally try. I also loved the vibe inside which was relaxed but cosy. All the chefs and our waitress were super helpful and friendly.
I love the speakeasy entrance through a nondescript bar. We had some great sake as well.
I would definitely come back here for another meal. I ordered the ramen as my main and it was great as well. I really enjoyed the course with the leafs and sticks addition as an aesthetic experience. The plate was also delicious.
The sushi and kaseki were decent. The crab dish was delicious as was the ramen one. The fish selection was pretty basic but they were decently cured.
Incredible kaiseki. Intimate atmosphere. Friendly and  knowledgeable staff.  Expert chef preparations. If I could afford it, I would eat here once a week!

Went here before they became more of a kaiseki place. I liked the balance of the courses and remember the dishes more for the presentation and balance more so than the sushi. I completely understand why they are more kaiseki focused, they are simply better at presenting cooked seasonal dishes. Worth a stop.

Had a chance to try Odo's kaiseki meal recently and was really pleased by the meal. The entrance is hidden behind a bar, where you can grab a drink before or after dinner. The bar up front has small bites, unrelated to Odo in the back.

The service is impeccable. This isn't unusual. At a place like this, the chefs and servers are attentive and you're taken well care of. I liked that I didn't feel rushed during this experience.

There's only one menu. My date chose the sake which paired nicely with our meal. At one point during the kaiseki, you have the option to choose between 3 items. We chose all of them and suggest you do too, as each item is different and beautifully made.

Every course was exquisite and you can tell the chef puts a lot of care into his work. Hard to choose highlights of the meal.. The broths were outstanding and the dessert at the end was a nice highlight.

It's tough to compare with Shuko since the styles are different, and I'd definitely give Odo a try. We had a great time and I'm sure you will too.
very good food. excellent balance of tasting. premium food material. great staff.

TLDR: a TRUE DELIGHT in the time of COVID.

A friend had suggested Odo (Aug 2020) and I was hesitant based upon the previous reviews during the same timeframe. But I was SO, so impressed with both the service and the food. We had an amazing time - great food, drinks and felt super safe.

The owner was so accommodating- we brought our small dog and it was raining, so without us having to ask, he brought out a small placemat for our pup to sit on so he didn't have to sit on the wet floor.

The food was delicious. The maguro tasting is a must - as well as the sushi rolls (bozushi). We had the salmon, anago and wagyu. Random but their edamame is OUT OF THIS WORLD. TRY IT - you will not regret it.

And then the service itself. The servers are THE picture of Japanese hospitality and when we left, we actually left a shopping bag behind. The server ran down the street, looking for us, to make sure we got it.

These people honestly deserve 5 stars for everything they're doing right now. We need to be supporting restaurants right now, especially one as good as Odo.

Thank you Odo for an awesome meal!

KenScale: 8.0/10

In the course of our culinary journey together, my wife Jun and I have become increasingly conscious of the value component. Restaurants in New York City are in general more expensive than most cities around the world, and knowing Jun is a wonderful cook at home I no longer felt obliged to check out every single new restaurant in the city. In other words, we wanted to make sure we visit places that are actually worth the money. That value factor becomes even more acute at expensive tasting menu restaurants; while Per Se is a very good restaurant, it was not wonderful enough to justify over $350 per person before drinks. Other times, we felt so lucky to indulge on the meal at Atomix for slightly over $200 per person. I've been meaning to check out Odo for a while with all the wonderful reviews coming from the press; the key question was going to be whether the $200 per person price tag for the restaurant's kaiseki menu was going to be worth it. We did have a good meal at Odo, but concluded that the value proposition was a bit shaky.

The kaiseki menu at Odo consists of a few starters followed by a series of sushi nigiris, then a few more savory courses and a seasonal cocktail and dessert combination. While we both appreciated the creativity behind each dish, we also felt short of marveling at how delicious it was. The use of caviar and cacao nibs on top of black sesame tofu in the first sakizuke course, for instance, was quite smart but the flavor of caviar and cacao nibs didn't quite gel together. While the bluefin toro in the owan dish was well-cooked, Jun found the broth to be slightly fishy. We both loved the gindara misozuke using sablefish from Canada, but wondered if the dish would've been even better with the truffle on top that somewhat overpowered the fish's flavor. Compared to the first few starter courses, the sushi course at Odo was quite consistently good. During the sushi course, chef Seong Cheol Byun came in front of our counter and started expertly preparing each nigiri. To my surprise, he noted that the vast majority of sushi at Odo is not sourced from Japan but from fishermen in NYC's vicinity like Montauk with personal connections to chef Hiroki Odo. Moreover, he said, the rice during our course was sourced from a noted rice master in Japan. Whether it's from the freshness of the ingredients or the optimal firmness of rice, most of the pieces we tried were actually quite good, from the very chewy pollock and tile fish (both from Long Island) to the Florida jack fish to blowtorched New Jersey bonito with radish on top. If Mr. Byun wants to open his own sushi shop one way, I have no doubt he will do very well. Following the wonderful sequence of sushi nigiris, the last two savory courses were also good but not particularly memorable. The takiwase dish with washugyu, tofu shabu shabu and burdock had aromatic flavor overall, but Jun and I had had better quality meats elsewhere. For the gohan course, Jun got the shrimp tempura soba while I got the king crab ramen. I tried both and didn't come away with lasting impression; the broth of the ramen didn't have the depth I would usually savor from a tonkotsu bowl, and the soba noodle's texture was strangely not very firm. For the dessert course, our server brought out a seasonal cocktail menu made with shochu and sparkling wine in front of the diners. It was a refreshing drink, but we were slightly puzzled why the kitchen only brought out a slice of dates monaka with sake kasu ice cream inside. We would've expected something a little bit more elaborate for a $200 per person meal.

Getting a reservation at Odo wasn't too difficult although the counter was more often than not full with diners coming in and out. The minimalistic dining room was perhaps too much quiet, giving an eerie vibe to the overall atmosphere of the restaurant. We shared a bottle of dry sake to complement the meal and there are also expensive wine bottles available. The service was also somewhat off; not that we care about a server bowing to us in 90 degrees at the end of the meal to express gratitude (which is fairly typical in Japanese restaurants that deeply value hospitality), but Jun couldn't help but notice that our server bowed in front of an American diner sitting next to me while not doing so to us. In any event, while Odo was overall a good restaurant, especially in the sushi course where I would love to come back for, we both felt a bit sad having shelled out a lot of money at the place. Is this a new norm for expensive Japanese sushi and kaiseki restaurants in the city? Perhaps our taste and expectation are a little bit more stringent when it comes to Asian food, but the visit to Odo really made me think about giving the value component of a restaurant more weight in our culinary journey.

You won't find a streetfront sign or window for Odo at all; instead, it's nestled through a hallway behind Hall, the speakeasy-like lounge that is on the street (and has no signage either). Without any natural light or being close to the street, you do feel like you have been transported away for an intimate dining experience once you have made your way back. I'm not a huge fan of the reservation system here; you can select a given time to sit down, but we waited almost 15 minutes in Hall before being escorted back to take our seat, and then we had to wait until everyone in our half of the counter seating (which was 6 of us) was present before the meal could start. It'd be much easier (and have less dead time) if they simply did 4 nightly seatings (with 2 staggered by 15-30 minutes from the other), as that is effectively what happens. Once seated, though, the meal is very well-paced, and given the front-row seat to the kitchen, you can see a lot of the preparation in action. I would also give props to the gentleman who was in charge of the drink advice and served some of the dishes - he knew his stuff inside and out and was very helpful in giving me advice on which sake to try. The drink menu is fairly limited - unlike Hall, there are no cocktails (except as part of the tasting menu) or beer selections, just sake and wine - but given the delicate nature of the food served here, there is no need to have other types of alcohol listed.

The food here is presented as a kaiseki tasting menu covering 8 courses, with one of the courses being an 8-piece sushi omakase tasting within the meal. Because of the natural setup of the space, the sushi was served from a bit of a mobile / compact kit, with all the fish pre-sliced (which did lend itself to it not coming off as fresh as it could have been). Overall, I found the sushi to be decent, if not the best selection of fish you would ordinarily find. The rest of the meal was pretty good as well, with the highlights being the starting bite (uni and caviar served over a cauliflower puree - a nice mix of creamy decadence with a heartier base), as well as the grilled sablefish, which had a very nice peanut curry glaze that is a hint of more of a southeast Asian flavor, but a bit more subtle. The fish was also cooked to a perfect buttery texture. The choice of the 'gohan' - a truffled ramen with egg in it - was a nice, warm finish to the savory courses, although it did tend a little towards the salty side. That said, I did find the dessert (an ice cream sandwich) to be somewhat simple, and the beef dish - cooked with wagyu cross-bred with Angus - to be served in a flavorful broth, but the beef itself was either a chewier cut or simply not cooked enough.

On balance, the food at Odo is well-executed on balance, and the setting provides for a very cozy dining experience. It's not the best kaiseki I have had, and there are a couple things that could be done better, but it's an excellent addition to the continually impressive Japanese food scene in NYC.

This place comes on top of my list for Kaiseki, price and freshness quality wises. Tried their Dinner and its very good within the price range. Not every dish gives me the Wow, but rather simple and neat comparing to many other Japanese cuisine in NYC at the moment. Totally recommend for dinner especially when you cannot travel far to Japan. My favourite is their Anago(sea eel), since its hard to find here! And hands down to the pickles too.

We decided to go for Valentine's Day. First, we were thrilled they staggered the seatings, so it was extremely intimate. Almost like we had a nearly 1:1 experience with the chef.

Second, the food was wonderful. The February menu is great. This was our best tasting menu experience out of a half dozen or so in the last year. The wagyu-style beef entree was probably my favorite, aside from a few of the 8 sushi selections! The sushi being handmade in front of us was awesome and added to the experience.

There was a small interruption in service that they couldn't avoid unfortunately, but they handled it wonderfully and made sure our experience was still great! Thank you to Michael, who was hosting us!

I was one of the early supporters of ODO, having gone right after the soft open, so it's especially disappointing to write this.  

We had a memorably unpleasant experience tonight before even eating, who said, in the course of a 5 minute conversation about an error in booking time, accused us (his customers) of "deflecting," asked us to "lower your voice" replete with waving hand gestures, and then dramatically slammed the booking tablet and said  "you have two choices - you can wait or you can leave and we'll charge you the cancellation fee."  All this after saying that he recognised me as one of the early supporters.  Needless to say, after being issued an ultimatum by an enterprise supposedly in the customer service business, we left.  

Setting aside who's at fault, this is not the treatment one should ever be on the receiving end of--it left me and my guest feeling condescended to and insulted.  To me, it reveals a shallowness and lack of class that reflects poorly on what underlying values ODO represents.  I have and will continue to visit Hirohisa, Okuda, and the other great restaurants in New York who treat their customers, no matter what the issue, with grace.  

Sadly, I will not return to ODO.  Please keep the cancellation fee, I hope it was worth it.  

If the management responds, I'm sure they will say they follow policy.   So, ODO, please see second and third paragraph.  And ask yourself if, regardless of food quality, this is who you want to be.

I'm quite disappointed.
The service was good. But the food did not stand out in any ways.
Everything is locally sourced. Sushi here is the worst I ever had for a restaurant in this price range. Fish was tasteless and I'm not even sure it's fresh as I had diarrhea the next day. A few courses were too salty for me.
I'd say this place is a straight rip off at $200 per person.

tonight i dined at odo for the second time. everything was superb. from the moment you enter the restaurant you're in a deeply sacred space. every course is exquisite. both months my favorite course was the sushi, which is terrifically fresh and balanced. it melts in your mouth. i'm pescatarian, and the chefs go above and beyond to accommodate me. last month they replaced the meat course with blowfish for me and tonight they prepared toro in place of the duck. i couldn't have asked for anything better.

odo, yoko and anna are so kind. i've had wonderful experiences with everyone who works at odo, really. i can't wait to go back next month. i love you guys!

I really wanted to like this place but overall I was pretty disappointed.  Everything was very blend, nothing special, and for the price point I think it could have been much better.  But great service I love the decor and the ring and bracelet for the chopsticks and napkins! Super cute.

This is definitely one of the best places to enjoy authentic Japanese Kaiseki cuisine.

Price is $200 for 8 savory courses + dessert+ matcha green tea. Doesn't include taxes and gratuity.
And I really thought the price could be higher for such an amazing dining experience!!

Not only the food but the service , the atmosphere, the utensils, it's everything so perfect and makes you feel like you are not in Manhattan !!

The staff is super kind , Anna the hostess guides you to the restaurant from the bar , and when you enter the restaurant the chefs welcomes you with a smile and "Irasshaimase" (welcome in Japanese).
All the chefs explain each dish very detailed and you get to know every single detail about the dishes. Chef Takashi did a great job explaining about each dish in Japanese to me and my bosses which were very satisfied and happy with the dining experience at Odo. But No worries , if you don't understand Japanese they obviously can explain the dishes in English as well.

I have been to many Japanese restaurants and I work for Japanese restaurant myself and I can definitely tell you that this place is Amazing and it's totally worth the price!! They could even charge more for the quality they provide !!!
I will definitely go back and also recommend to all my friends !!!

The last savory course , they let us have the three options rice, sea food curry and tan tan noodle which was very kind and the cocktail that the sommelier made in front of us was superb!

The sushi : the chef Prepares in front of you so it is very entertaining and tastes great! They use only local fishes and my favorite was the Handroll.

If you are thinking about going to ODO , don't hesitate and make a reservation because it's simply amazing !!!!

After a delicious meal last year, we signed up for the mailing list. We were thrilled to hear that they were reopening with outdoor seating and immediately booked a reservation for 2 for a birthday dinner.

They have 5 2-top tables for outdoor seating - four of which are enclosed and covered, while one is on the walking path on the narrow sidewalk, seemingly reserved for walk-ins. After being seated in the exposed table despite our reservation, we requested to be moved to the enclosed area where there were tables available. Even though there were tables of equal size and seating, the waitress and manager both refused. After they made no further attempt to accommodate us, we decided we could not spend 100s of dollars at a business that felt entitled to our money without offering the usual service or hospitality. As our first meal outside during COVID, we were shocked at the way we were treated with birthday reservations.

We left and will never return. I can only assume this decision was due to the way we were dressed - we live in the neighborhood so we came down in tshirts and jeans. We walked a few blocks away to another restaurant where they welcomed us without reservations and had a delicious meal.
A adventure without having to endure the long transit to Tokyo. Terrific Kaiseki dinner with locovore fish and elements. Had the 3 starch option, ramen chazuke and soba. Wonderful service. A delight,

I had the good fortune to be able to order one of the New Years osechi home delivery before they sold out. It was the best osechi I have had in my life. Sooo wonderfully fresh, varied, and surprising. Two stacked lacquer boxes each with slightly different characteristics. Fantastic, gorgeous presentation. So decedent, so nourishing in its flavors. It made me so happy! I'm glad to know where to find osechi next year! I will be ordering again.
I've had a lot of pizza before. This is really, really good! Slightly crispy bottom, perfectly spiced sausage and pepperoni, and halal to boot!  Well done!

I visited nyc a week ago and had to review this place. I lost my mom the day I came here, my finance and I spent most of the day cooped in a police. Station filing a missing persons report. Needless to say we were distraught.

Afterwards we had to get a drink so we came in here and to our surprise, there was my mom. Taking jager bombs with the boys. Turns out she decided turned this place into her home on account for the sick beats and slappin vibes. In short, Off the wagon brought my family back together.

Came here on a Saturday night around 10. It was fine. There's a beer pong table upstairs, which seems to usually have an informal line. No real way of determining order so you just have to be attentive and know where you are in the queue. Pretty sure the bartender double charged me, unless two draft Blue Moons really cost $27 lol

I've been coming here for a while now but haven't been in about 6 years. Once I walked in I was met with the same exact vibe as if I never left.

They play great alternative oldies. The bartenders have always given great service and the drinks are affordable for the bar being located near w4.

I'm here with my wife and it's definitely our kind of date spot. A wooden bar, good music, delicious drinks and a chill vibe. Definitely an after work spot for its happy hour, and it's clean for an NY bar.

There's two levels and tvs located on almost every wall, giving you the best of all sports.

I love coming here for a drink before heading to the Christopher street pier.

Check it out!
They could not make an old fashioned, no simple syrup or serve a proper martini. Relatively clean. But, what a sh_ty bar.

Decent bar to grab a drink. Offers a laidback atmosphere, good pricing for NYC, and a cool location in Greenwich village. As the bartender says "it's a party bar not a cocktail bar" so they only offer your beers and basic cocktails nothing fancy.

House made fried pickles and chicken burger for lunch. Super good. They allow kids in here before 4pm. Frankly, we just stopped to use the bathroom and for my husband to grab a beer (so that I could use the bathroom), ended up staying for lunch.

Going to make this short and sweet. Ordered a Hendricks and soda - the first sip? There's absolutely no way that's Hendricks... no way. I drink Hendricks enough to know the flavor and that wasn't it. Not sure how this place operates but you're definitely not getting what you ordered... unless it's bottom of the barrel.

Next...
Dope spot in nyc. Came here on my visit with cousins and it was a nice vibe. Drinks were good Dj was good will def be returning

Amazing spot to get drunk and party with friends for cheap. A dive bar with beer games located on the top level and dance floor/bar at the bottom. Great loud music to dance and party to. Entire street is buzzing with people. Depending on the crowd it may take some time to order drinks but the quality and price is worth it. Typical beer selection at the bar. Definitely recommend a night out to party with friends and spend within limits.

If you want to relive your college days as a partying frat boy or sorority girl this is your bar!

Nothing wrong with reliving the fun days before adulting really had to start. Along with bills, responsibilities, and real life.

14 beers on tap, happy hour until 7 pm, beer and a shot for $10 deal, pub grub. Typical beer selection but nothing craft wise which will blow you away.

Seltzer beers, red bull, and college drunkenness kind of place. Decent mix of old and new rock playing. Plenty of flat screens with the games on. Booths to hang out in with your crew. Upstairs bar area too.

Yeah, it's loud in here but that's what's expected of a college targeted party bar.
This place is so awesome. Solid food. The drinks were all fairly priced. So many tvs for the games. Highly recommend.

Stumbled into this bar walking around this area waiting for show to start. Got sucked in by the happy house of $2 off all bar items 5-7pm Monday to Friday.
The bar tender was super friendly  it has a dive bar vibe very bro kinda sports bar. A lot of people were here for a drink before the show at this hour.

Enjoyed a fantastic St. Patrick's Day at Off The Wagon.  Jordan, our waiter was fantastic.  He helped us the entire night.  The food is incredible.  Complements to the chef AND bartender.  

COVID-19 safety measures in place outside and indoors.
Love this place they have  cheep beer weekends cool vibe not sure of they have beer pong

This is definitely a pregame spot. The happy hour drinks  were $7. I had 2 tequila rises , garlic parm wings & loaded tater tots that includes bacon & cheese. The music is pretty good as they do play it all. On Fridays they have a live DJ at 10pm & it changes the whole vibe of the place for the good. The service is bomb. The bartenders are heavy handed (good to me)

If there was an option of no stars was available, that would be my rating . This was a first and definitely last time I walk into this place . The rudeness started with the ID checker, who was no where in sight when we walked in , but nearly chased us to the bar stools . Next the 2 bartenders who were more concerned with each other, and checking out the young college girls (eww) than actually serving us drinks . We were never asked if we wanted a 2nd drink or food , more so the frat bartenders were busy checking out the college girls . Stay away and don't believe the hype at this place .

I know this may come off as a Karen but I swear it's not.   I came here Sunday with a few gfs and MItCH the bartender may have been the rudest bartender in the 15 years I've lived in nyc.   (Check my yelp reviews no bad ones) I asked for an orange slice not knowing they only they had limes (I guess that's my fault).   Followed by asking for a Togo drink which is cool.  Off the wagon doesn't do it. But the service I received after those two questions was so soo sooo rude!!!   I asked to close out my check.  He didn't give me my credit card and when I asked for it he THREW it across the bar towards me and said derogatory words towards me.   Beware of Mitch being your trashy bartender
Great bar and atmosphere! Loved the music and wish I knew the playlist. Great for watching sports and spending time with friends.

Decent place to grab a quick drink while waiting for dinner or to sit and watch a little bit of a game on the multiple TVs they have at the bar. Drinks are decent, bartenders are efficient, and prices are fairly reasonable for the area.

Tremendously rude, pricey, and unsanitary. Went here to watch the World Cup since every other bar in Manhattan was packed today. Sat at the bar with family and had the worst experience here. Waitress was completely unprofessional and routinely made obscene gestures behind the counter, Mid tier shots were priced at an egregious $15 a pop, and absurd comments and unsanitary practices were REPLETE by our server. Worst of all, after spending over $100 on drinks and food we were told to leave the bar area because we hadn't ordered anything in 15 minutes with 10 minutes left in the game nonetheless. It was unmistakably my worst experience in any establishment. PLEASE Don't come here and don't support this business by any means. How my family and I were treated today was utterly disgraceful!
One of the Best Darty Bars in NYC; cheap beer, strong drinks, and upstairs has pong tables! $20 pitchers of beer. 5/5 stars as a day bar.

Rudest bartender I've ever incountered in my entire life. Asked how I was going pay before I even order a drink bc a friend of mine was trying to get her attention while she was taking shots at the other end of the bar and not paying attention to other patrons.
Drinks were not good as well. Run from this place there are ten other bars in the neighborhood with better service and drinks.
Great place to watch NY Giants games. Two floors, many TVs and great food. Six short block walk to PATH 9th Street.
It's a college sports bar. So you get what you sign up for. The music was fun and bartenders were super nice and fast, prices were in line with what you'd expect. No fancy review required!

Pretty cool place to grab a drink. The street was bustling on a Thursday early evening. It was a bit busy, but my buddy and I were able to grab a seat. There's a 2 hour limit if it gets busy, but I don't think it ever got to that point. Service was fast and friendly. I was crushing hard on our waitress. I felt like every time she came over she was gonna tell me something, like "I love you" but that might be wishful drinking, or because of the 4th Goose Island beer I had within the hour. Ordered a side of Mac and Cheese wedges, amazing choice if I do say so myself. I love the dipping sauce, it was just a small cup of Louisiana hot sauce or something. Most places are so skimpy on the sauce/dip, but there was more than enough sauce here. However, there's like 7 wedges total, so definitely looked bare.

Had an embarrassing story at the bathroom. I thought it was one of those solo toilets, so when I tried to push the door open, I thought it was locked and preceded to wait outside. Another guy comes and asked if I was waiting for the bathroom, which I replied with Yes. Then I started to realize the door might be a pull. And yes it was. We were waiting outside like idiots for a hot minute. The bathroom also had 2 urinals and 1 toilet, enough to fit 3 whole people (4 if you're feeling frisky!). We had a good laugh about it, but there should be a sign that says "Pull" on it. Or they did that on purpose for the giggles.

Anyways, cool place. Street has a good vibe for drinks

Best bar ever !
Not only amazing bar food but Draft beer always on point.

Great music. Great atmosphere

Drinks: 3/5
Decent drinks, not too strong, not too weak. Decent beer selection. I wouldn't order wine or speciality cocktails here. Sort of more like your college bar.

Service: 4/5
No complaints. Very nice and accommodating?

Ambiance: 2/5
Dive bar. Music is a bit too loud for my preference. Not a good place for a date. It's so loud you can barely hold a conversation. Dark and dingy. Not my scene.

Wow! Blown away by the service! Jordan is an absolute ANGEL!! And to add to that he's cute too. He let us know that the cheapest thing on the menu was to order a $2 hotdog, which he even offered to eat for us!!!! Anyways tequila sunrises were bomb and he was super patient with us. a+ will return to off the wagon

What can I say? I always hate lengthy reviews, but it's important here. For nearly 25 years between their sister spot Jake's on Amsterdam Ave and Off The Wagon, I was a very loyal customer. Mostly for the low drink prices and familiarity I found. I got to know a number of folks at the bars and guess I felt comfortable. About 8 years ago one night I forgot to pay my tab. First and last time in my life that has happened. Mortified and embarrassed, the next day I paid it off entirely along with a hefty tip and huge apology. I was still banned. Evidently forever. For that. Although I'm sure this is a common mistake especially with the college crowd, I was really hurt given my long run of loyalty. A few days ago I stopped back in to say hello for old time's sake. An unnecessarily intimidating security guy recognized me and turned me away, quite rudely in fact. 8 years later. Mind boggling. Not just the unforgiving part, but the way it was handled and how I was treated in the process. It's very sad.
